title: 103_hr3646
content: The Act titled "Meat and Poultry Products Inspection Amendments of 1993" is referred to as the short title. It involves federal and state cooperation under the Federal Meat Inspection Act. The Federal Meat Inspection Act of 1993, also known as the "Meat and Poultry Products Inspection Amendments," removes the limitation on intrastate distribution, allows the use of state inspectors, and terminates the designation of states subject to federal inspection for intrastate distribution. The Federal Meat Inspection Act of 1993 expands state inspection authority for establishments not under federal inspection, allowing states to regulate slaughter and distribution of certain animals for human food. The Federal Meat Inspection Act of 1993 allows equines prepared under State inspection to be sold in interstate commerce and used in establishments with Federal inspection. State inspected articles are not eligible for foreign commerce and must be kept separate from federally inspected articles in establishments. The Federal Meat Inspection Act of 1993 allows equines prepared under State inspection to be sold in interstate commerce and used in establishments with Federal inspection. State inspected articles are not eligible for foreign commerce and must be kept separate from federally inspected articles in establishments. Carcasses, parts of carcasses, meat, and meat food products inspected in a State program must bear official marks identifying the State, and operators can only transfer between State and Federal inspection on October 1 of any year. Operators can transfer between State and Federal inspection on October 1 of any year with written notice and approval from the Secretary. Additionally, operators can transfer at any time if they provide evidence of engaging in foreign commerce. Interstate commerce is defined as commerce between States or between a State and the District of Columbia. Interstate commerce is defined as commerce between States or between a State and the District of Columbia. Section 408 of the Act prohibits any State or Territory from imposing additional or different requirements on establishments beyond those outlined in the Act. A State or Territory cannot impose additional requirements on establishments beyond those outlined in the Act. They may exercise concurrent jurisdiction with the Secretary over articles in commerce to ensure compliance with the Act. The Act allows States and Territories to impose requirements consistent with the Act on matters regulated under the Act. Federal and state cooperation is required under the Poultry Products Inspection Act. The Poultry Products Inspection Act allows for the removal of intrastate distribution limitations and the use of state inspectors for examinations and inspections. Additionally, the designation of a state as subject to federal inspection for intrastate distribution can be terminated. The Poultry Products Inspection Act allows state inspection for poultry products processed in compliance with state laws to be eligible for interstate commerce and use. The Poultry Products Inspection Act allows state-inspected poultry products to be used in establishments with federal inspection, but they cannot be sold or transported in foreign commerce. The Poultry Products Inspection Act allows state-inspected poultry products to be used in establishments with federal inspection, but they cannot be sold or transported in foreign commerce. State-inspected poultry products must be identified with official marks prescribed by the State, while federally inspected poultry products must use official marks prescribed by the Secretary. Establishments under Federal or State inspection can transfer to State or Federal inspection on October 1 of any year with a six-month notice to both agencies. The transfer must align with legislative policy and not disrupt the inspection systems. The Secretary may allow transfer from State to Federal inspection if there is evidence of substantial engagement in foreign commerce. The text discusses the definition of interstate commerce and prohibits states from imposing additional requirements on official establishments beyond those outlined in the Act. The text prohibits states from imposing additional requirements on establishments beyond those outlined in the Act, allowing concurrent jurisdiction with the Secretary over articles distributed in commerce. The Act grants the Secretary concurrent jurisdiction over articles in commerce to prevent distribution of non-compliant items for human consumption. States can enforce regulations consistent with the Act on other matters regulated under it.
